ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned pretty much all of the bones in the human body and muscles and ligaments that attach/insert.
what a great class. i learned a lot about the body and bones
Knowledge of human osteology and bones, skills how to evaluate fossils/physical artifacts/ use them to study
Learned all the bones in the human skeleton, how to side them and their features in the nervous and muscular system.
You learn every bone in the body, its various features, how to side each feature, how to determine baseline osteological profiles and the associated muscles with each features.
Learned how to identify all the different bones in the body and different features of them. Learned muscle and ligament attachments

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: No weaknesses. I love that the class is very structured.
i think it can be a jumpscare to the amount of memorization this class requires but if you just focus in its possible.
well taught, interesting, challenging in a good way. zero weaknesses.

The course requires some memorization of muscle attachments in the second half, but lab time and specimens did not address this. It would be helpful to dedicate a day (and indicate this on the syllabus) to pull out soft-tissue specimens so that students may prepare for this ahead of time.

There really aren't any weaknesses to this course. Dr. Sargis gives you every chance to succeed here as long as you prepare for class (make a quizlet using the study guide and study it everyday for a half and hour) and go to lab sessions. Exams and quizzes are clearly outlined and cover what is exactly on the study guide. Again, as long as you go to class and study, you should have no problem as its just memorization.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yes. but you need to be ready to put in the work
Absolutely. An amazing course overall and great for a better understanding of the human body.
Yes, to an anthropology or premed student.

Yes if they are interested in learning more about human skeletal anatomy. This class is pretty difficult to get into (the whole class is basically seniors who are pre-med or occasional archaeology/anthropology majors) so you should really be sure its something you are both interested in and is useful to you later on.

Yes! Dr. Sargis does a great job at keeping the content interesting, and he's very lenient on what you do during the lab sections of the course. He helps out anybody who needs it and will check in to see if you're doing alright in the class.
Yes! I really enjoyed this class and felt that I learned a lot. I always looked forward to the labs!
